awd_abstract_narration: This award is made as part of the FY 2016 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Emily Leven is "The Combinatorics of Macdonald Eigenoperators." The host institution for the fellowship is the University of Pennsylvania, and the sponsoring scientist is James Haglund.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit:

The main focus of the project was the further investigation of Macdonald polynomials and their eigenoperators. The Macdonald polynomials are an amazing symmetric function basis introduced by Macdonald and modified by Garsia and Haiman. Numerous results and conjectures about their eigenoperators connect combinatorics, symmetric function theory, representation theory, and algebraic geometry.

The famous Shuffle Theorem relates one such eigenoperator to the combinatorics of labeled Dyck paths. A theorem of Haiman connects these both to the representation theory of the ring of diagonal coinvariants of S_n. The eigenoperator formula and combinatorial formula were generalized to the Delta Conjecture by Haglund, Remmel, and Wilson. However, there is no analog of the ring of diagonal coinvariants that has been proven to give representation-theoretic meaning to the Delta Conjecture.

The PI, together with Qiu, Remmel, and Xin, gave the Schur expansion for the symmetric function appearing in a family of special cases of Delta Conjecture, providing evidence that the Delta Conjecture also has significance in representation theory. The PI and her sponsor also generalized a powerful tool from the Shuffle Theorem setting called "schedules". They were able to use these generalized schedules to better understand the combinatorics of the Delta Conjecture and to provide evidence that Zabrocki's ring of super-diagonal coinvariants was the correct Delta Conjecture-analog of the ring of diagonal coinvariants.

The PI also generalized the Shuffle Conjecture in a different direction, by exploring the action of the same Macdonald eigenoperator on the monomial symmetric function basis. And an exploration of unicellular LLT polynomials (which appear naturally in the Shuffle Conjecture and elsewhere) led the PI and her sponsor to invent a new tableaux statistic, answering a decade-old question of Assaf.

The PI has an ongoing research project with Naqvi and Sahi about interpolation polynomials, which are a non-homogeneous analog of Macdonald polynomials. This has recently yielded a beautiful combinatorial formula for the Jack analog which proves a nice positivity property. Another collaboration with Komlos and Tusnady resulted in a publication regarding the asymptotic distribution of the size of certain partitions. Finally, the PI and Johnson are preparing a preprint about a more efficient Littlewood-Richardson rule in type C.

 

Broader Impacts:

Throughout the duration of this postdoctoral fellowship, the PI continued her strong support of minorities in mathematics. Most notably, the PI served on multiple national committees for the Association for Women in Math, and was the chair of the national Student Chapters Committee (July 2018 - January 2020). Through this service, the PI has organized many opportunities for female students, making connectons with and providing guidance to nearly 200 AWM Student Chapters nation-wide.

The PI also participated in Project NExT, an MAA teaching program for early career mathematicians. The program provided training in active learning and other research-based pedagogical methods, which the PI has applied in her teaching at her host institution and at her subsequent institution (Rutgers University). Such methods have been shown to improve learning outcomes and to increase inclusiveness in the classroom.


Last Modified: 12/18/2020
Modified by: Emily Sergel
